intro: Brassica juncea var. rugosa, commonly known as Chinese mustard or hairy mustard, is a cultivar of the mustard plant characterized by its rough, hairy leaves. It is an annual plant native to China and belongs to the Brassicaceae family. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring dark green, serrated leaves covered in fine hairs. It produces small yellow flowers in clusters, followed by round, pale yellow or green siliques that contain numerous seeds. This variety is often grown for its edible leaves and seeds, which are used in various culinary and medicinal applications.
